event.desc: Simeon travelled far and wide to preach against the followers of Theodore, Nestorius, Mani, Bar Daisan, and Marcion. He travelled from Jerusalem to Illyricum and Persia and Constantinople to spread the Christian faith.

occupation.note: Theodore was a bishop of Mopsuestia.

event.desc: Hiba the Bishop of Edessa allowed certain heresies to spread in Edessa, such as Nestorianism, which was promoted by the School of the Persians.
Bishop Cyrus of Edessa was opposed to the School of the Persians and stopped it from flourishing in Edessa. The School moved to Nisbis.
Simeon travelled wherever heresy was taking root and debated with those who promoted heresy until they all fell silent.

Simeon travelled as far as the camp of the Saracens of the Tribe of Nu'man and converted many to Christianity. He persuaded certain magnates who had converted to Christianity build Christian churches.

personGrp.persName: Saracens of the Tribe of Nu'man
The magnates who built Christian churches after they converted to Christianity.

event.desc: Simeon also battled the Magian heresy and converted three great distinguished Magians to Christianity.

personGrp.persName: The thee distinguished Magians who converted to Christianity

event.desc: The King was informed about the three distinguished Magians who converted to Christianity and ordered them to renounce Christianity on pain of death.

person.persName:
The King who ordered the death of
the three distinguished Magians who converted to Christianity.

event.desc: The newly converted Christians (formerly Magian) refused to renounce Christianity and were put to the sword. They became martyrs for the Christian faith.

state.note: The three distinguished magians who converted to Christianity were martyrs.

event.desc: Simeon travelled through Persia and to Rome in order to convert more people to Christianity.
The Nestorian bishops met with the King of Persia, The Magian, and warned him about the dangerous presence of the Christians in his country. They urged the King to order a persecution of Christians.
Simeon met with Roman Emperor Anastasius and asked him to urge the Persian King to let the Christians in Persia live in peace. Anastasius convinced King Kawad to leave the Persian Christians alone.
Simeon gained a reputation among the leaders and doctors of the heretical movements in various countries for being a great debater. He was nicknamed the Invincible Satan Simeon the debater.

person.persName: The Invincible Satan Simeon the debater

event.desc: Because Simeon humiliated so many heretical leaders whenever he debated with them, many wanted him dead. In order to move about in safety, Simeon wore his hair and beard long in the style of a Persian layman.
Simeon visited the Christians in Hirtha Nu'man
Babai, Catholicus of Seleucia called a debate among the bishops in Persia, which Simeon participated in after they appointed the King's Marzban as the moderator.

occupation.note:
Babai was the patriarch of
Seleucia
This man was the King's marzban.

event.desc: The Marzban declared Simeon the winner of the debate with Babai. Simeon's easy victory humiliated the Nestorians and prompted the Christian bishops to convince Simeon to be promoted to Bishop of Beth Arsham.
Simeon was ordained Bishop of Beth Arsham

occupation.note:
Simeon was ordained Bishop of
Beth Arsham

event.desc: The King of Persia ordered all of the Christian bishops and archimandrites to be arrested and put in a prison in Nisbis for seven years.
The King of Aethiopia, who was a Christian, sent his ambassadors to ask the Persian King to release the Christian bishops and archimandrites.

sex.note: The King of Aethiopia was male.

personGrp.persName:
The ambassadors of the
Aethiopian king.

event.desc: After seven hard years in prison, Simeon was released.
For seven years, Simeon travelled to different Christian communities in order to confirm their belief in the Christian faith.
The Persian King died and was succeeded by his son.
The Nestorian faith flourished under King Khosrau

Simeon asked the Queen of the Romans to send a letter to the Queen of the Persians concerning the safety of the Christian community in Persia. The Roman Queen complied with his wish and kept the aged and very frail Simeon close to her until the end of his life.

occupation.note: Theodora was the Empress of Rome.

sex.note: The Queen of Persia was female.

occupation.note: This person was the Queen of Persia.

event.desc: Simeon died
Simeon's presbyter stayed with the good Christian patrician Probus for two years, where he managed Simeon's extensive collection of sermons and letters. Simeon's presbyter died.
